images.tombstone:
David Roberts |(Scottish, 1796–1864)
The Fortress of the Alhambra, Granada|, 1836
Oil on canvas
Harvard Art Museums/Fogg Museum, Gift of Richard L. Feigen

The Alhambra and Generalife
Present view
images.description: Roberts's improbably high point of view from the roof of an imaginary building close to the Mirador de San Nicolás in Granada allows him to fit more into the view than a human eye can capture

images.tombstone:
Darley, Felix Octavius Carr
(American, 1822–1888)
Frontispiece. From Washington Irving, The Alhambra, rev. ed.
New York: G. P. Putnam, 1851
Chrysler Museum of Art, Jean Outland Chrysler Library
images.description: One of the iconic views of the Tower of Comares from below, publicized thanks to the numerous etchings and reproductions in travel books

images.tombstone:
Mary Bradish Titcomb
(American, 1858-1927)
The Alhambra, ca. 1906
Chrysler Museum of Art, Museum
Purchase with funds given in memory of Joan Foy French by her daughters Wendy and Christina
images.description: The Tower of Comares, also prominent on Roberts's panorama, was among the most popular sites of the Alhambra. Artists had a convenient poin of view from the Darro River to capture the sight

images.tombstone: The Tower of Comares, current view
images.description: One can see that, in order to capture the Alhambra closely, the artists were challenged by the lack of a view point that would not make the grand fortress look less grand on the steep hill.

images.tombstone:
Mariano Fortuny |(Spanish, 1838-1874)
The Slaughter of the Abencerrajes|, 1870
Oil on canvas
Museu Nacional d'Art de Catalunya
The Hall of Abencerrajes, current view
images.description: The Hall of Abencerrajes--a large room off the Patio de los Leones-- received this name after the legend of the slaughter of thirty members of a powerful family of the Abencerrajes by the father of Boabdil, the last ruler of the Kingdon of Granada. Several versions of this legend circulated in the chronicles and the oral poetry among the christian and the morisco (baptized muslim) communities, but the origins of the legen are confusing. An important mythological element of these stories is the alabaster fountain, shose waters were tainted by the blood of the victims.

images.tombstone:
Rodriguez, Rafael Garzón
(Spanish, 1863-1923)
Granada, Sala del Tribunal de Justicia. (Alhambra). Granada Interior de la Sala de los Abencerrajes. (Alhambra) 1870-1900
University of California, Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive
William K. Ehrenfeld M.D. Collection
images.description: The photograph on the right captures a view of the Hall of the Abencerrajes--the location of Fortuny's painting--in Fortuny's times. You can see how Fortuny transforms the location into a decoration for an operatic scene, blurring the architectural details while also making them recognizable for those familiar with the space.

images.tombstone:
Muros Úbeda, Francisco
(Spanish, 1836-1917)
Sala de los Abencerrajes
1850-1917
Museo Casa de los Tiros, Granada
images.description: Mariano Fortuny, who lived in Granada at the time when he painted The Slaughter of the Abencerrajes hailed from a Catalan family and was connected through marriage to the family of the Madrazo, famous artists with cosmopolitan connections established in Madrid. (Federico de Madrazo, Fortuny's father-in-law, was a famous artist and director of The Prado museum.) Here is, in contrast, a painting from the same time by an artist rooted in Granada. Muros Úbeda's attention to historical detail and the costumes contrasts with Fortuny's approach to the scene, focused on the brightness of color.

images.tombstone:
Laurent, Jean
(French, 1816-1886)
GRANADA (Alhambra)- Sala de los Abencerrajes, interior view
1860-1886
Madrid, Instituto de Patrimonio Cultural de España
images.description: 19th-centuryartists often used Laurent's photographs for inspiration or verification of details.

images.tombstone:
Laurent, Jean
(French, 1816-1886)
GRANADA (Alhambra)- Sala de los Abencerrajes, interior view
1860-1886
Madrid, Instituto de Patrimonio Cultural de España
images.description: Complementing the previpus one, this photograph adds another angle to the view. Fortuny's composition combines both views by establishing an artificially constructed point of view, which in reality was impossible because the small size of the Hall would make the viewer hit the wall.

images.tombstone:
Camino
(Spanish, died 1888)
Granada, Patio de los Leones, Alhambra
ca. 1880
Chrysler Museum of Art
images.description: The location of Fortuny's scene, the Hall of the Abencerrajes, is right off the Patio de los Leones. Photographs often capture the Patio from that Hall.

images.tombstone:
William Merritt Chase |(American, 1849-1916)
Sunny Spain|, 1882
Oil on canvas
Collection of Lois and Arthur Stainman, New York

William Merritt Chase
(American, 1849-1916)
Outskirts of Madrid, 1882
Yale University Art Gallery, Gift of Duncan Phillips
images.description: Though it was finished almost forty years after the view of Toledo, this painting features a similar composition, with a wall on the right and the figures coded as typical and lower class. There is less insistence on the iconic "Spanishness" in this painting, however. Instead, we see a smoking pipe in the background--a sinister icon of modernization and its problems

images.tombstone:
Robert Frederick Blum
(American, 1857-1903)
Toledo Water-Carrier, ca. 1882
Fred Baker Collection
images.description: Mules were a popular part of the Spanish landscape among artists, as demonstrated on this painting, also set in Toledo. Note also the sue of the red details by both artists

images.tombstone:
Walter Gay |(American, 1856-1937)
Cigarette Girls, Seville|, 1895
Oil on canvas
Colby College Museum of Art, Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Bronson Griscom

Samuel Colman
(American, 1838-1920)
Washing Day, ca. 1872
Oil on canvas, , tacked over panel
Private Collection

Torres Molina
(Spanish, ?????)
Reform of the Plaza Isabel la Católica de Granada, 02/13/1964
Archivo de IDEAL
images.description: The location of Coleman's scene, former embankment of the Darro, is now irrecognizable. Already in Coleman's time, works had begun to encase the river under the pavement of a new street, the Calle de Reyes Católicos. The section captured by Coleman became a street in 1936-1938. In 1962, Coleman's location becae the site of a new square, Plaza de Isabel la Católica

images.tombstone:
Torres Molina
(Spanish, ?????)
Reform of the Plaza Isabel la Católica de Granada, 1936
Archivo de IDEAL
images.description: The section captured by Coleman became a part of the paved calle de Reyes Católicos in 1936-1938.

images.tombstone:
John Frederick Lewis
(English, 1805 - 1876)
Alhambra from the Alameda del Darro, 1830s-1840s
Milwaukee Art Museum
images.description: Coleman's paintings fit into the popular genre of landscapes featuring the Granada bridges. Thought Lewis portrays a different bridge, the composition shares with Coleman's the loving treatment of the arches and the buildings coming close to the water.

images.tombstone:
Childe Hassam |(American, 1859-1935)
Church Procession, Spanish Steps|, ca. 1883
Oil on canvas
Private Collection

Ernest Lawson |(American, 1873-1939)
Segovia|, ca. 1916
Oil on canvas
Minneapolis Institute of Arts, The John R. Van Derlip Fund

Jean Laurent
(French, 1816-1886) and his studio
View of the Alcázar and the Cathedral of Toledo from Fuencisla, ca. 1870
Madrid, Instituto de Patrimonio Cultural de España
images.description: The similarities between Laurent's view and Lawson's landscape are as striking as their differences.  The photographer used  the point of view very similar to one inferred from the landscape. We can see, however, that Lawson changes the scale, making the cathedral belltower seem much higher. The Alcázar, still in ruins at the time of the photograph, was restored in the early 20th century.

images.tombstone:
Robert Henri
(American, 1865-1929)
Segovia, Spain, 1906
Collection of Stephen and Miriam Seidel
images.description: Henri visited Segovia in___. This painting offers a simler view over the cathedral

images.tombstone:
Carrie Hill
(American, 1875-1957)
View of Segovia, ca. 1925
Birmingham Museum of Art; Promised gift of Dr. Julius E. Linn, Jr.
images.description: The same view appears even more distorted than in Lawson's rendering, making the landscape resemple more El Greco's view of Toledo

images.tombstone:
Jean Laurent
(French, 1816-1886) and his studio
View of the Aqueduct of Segovia, ca. 1870
The Chrysler Museum of Arr
images.description: The aqueduct  is now considered Segovia's most prominent attraction. It is interesting, however, that it is nowhere to find on the views of Segovia featured here. In the 19th and early 20th centuries one would not travel to Spain hoping to find Roman monuments.

images.tombstone: Current view of Segovia from the Alcázar
images.description: This is a close current perspective of the Alcázar
